Award.AwardTitle: Scholars Award: Light Pollution's Social and Ecological Consequences and Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will analyze how scientists, research teams, and organizations have produced knowledge about environmental light pollution. The project will contribute to our understanding of the politics of artificial light at night and the history of nightscapes, and lightscapes. This project will expands empirical and analytical insights regarding the politics of environmental knowledge production. This study will bring critical social science perspectives to research impacts and responses on communities to artificial light at night. The findings from this project will contribute to conservation science, policymaking, and citizen science and will be made public through writings, conferences and educational activities.

Using approaches from science and technology studies and environmental history the project will examine how historical, cultural, institutional, and technoscientific factors shape what is known about artificial light at night and its socio-ecological consequences through citizen/expert approaches, cultural and political contexts, and public/private conservation efforts. The research will be done in collaboration with light pollution scientists, government agencies, and NGOs using archives, oral histories, interviews, and ethnographic observation. The project will contribute social science insights into light pollution and its role as growing socio-ecological issue that can indicate on a global-scale, anthropogenic environmental change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of this research grant, I investigated ground-based environmental light pollution in the natural and built environment through social science disciplines, including the history of science and technology, science and technology studies, and environmental history.

Light pollution—excessive, misdirected, and/or disruptive artificial light at night—is a growing socio-ecological issue; an index of global-scale, human-caused environmental change; and focus of conservation policy and politics. The problem has gotten worse since the late nineteenth century, especially since World War II, but many light-pollution researchers believe it will become even more severe in coming decades due to LED retrofits, human population growth, rising consumerism, development in the global South, and new technologies such as LEDs and solar panels intended to provide artificial light to remote rural areas.

Perhaps not surprisingly, then, light pollution has received increasing attention in science, policy, activism, and by the general public, particularly over the past decade. Despite this fact, it remains understudied in the social sciences. Because of this, potentially crucial insights from these disciplines with regard to history, culture, politics, political economy, and ethics have been largely lacking from light-pollution science, conservation, and advocacy—at the very moment when these arenas are at a vital crossroads in the early twenty-first century.

Astronomers first raised substantial concerns about light pollution in the early 1970s. Through quantitative analysis, this project shows a sharp increase in research about artificial light at night beginning in 2009, with the most significant rise being in ecological studies. Through qualitative analysis, it reveals how keywords describing nocturnal artificial light have varied over time and by discipline, with most terms describing artificial light at night as having negative connotations.

Through analysis of published studies and fieldwork at multiple sites in the United States and Europe, this research also demonstrates how artificial light at night’s local effects vary due to both natural (e.g., cloud cover, snowfall, forest composition) and cultural (e.g., lighting type, zoning, cultural preferences) factors. In this sense, “artificial” light is clearly a misnomer, as the term simplifies a complex phenomenon.

The project teases out how different scientific disciplines, including astronomy, ecology, and remote sensing help illuminate distinct aspects of nocturnal artificial light and its socio-ecological effects. Yet each discipline has its own limits. Given the complexity of the phenomenon and emergent state of research, however, a significant share of scientific studies are interdisciplinary, drawing on the expertise of multiple fields.

Regardless of discipline, through their research, scientists studying nocturnal artificial light ironically draw attention to night, its multifaceted importance, and its changes locally and globally, as part of anthropogenic environmental change. Their work suggests how night is a fundamental—yet largely understudied and unappreciated—environment.

While many scientists studying nighttime artificial light aim to separate science and activism, many use traditional environmentalist ideas to motivate their own research and explain why the issue matters to other scientists and to the public. However, people have unequal access to both artificial light at night and darkness within and across societies. They also experience its socio-environmental effects—positive and negative—differently, depending on factors such as race, ethnicity, class, gender, global North/South position, and urban/rural environments. Consequently, this research project demonstrates how nocturnal artificial light is an ethical and political issue that instead requires viewing through an environmental justice lens focused not only on protecting areas with what scientists call “natural” or “pristine night-sky brightness,” but also on addressing over-illumination at its source. It proposes “critical dark-sky studies” as a framework for investigating scientific, policy, and activist concerns about light pollution that also center these political and ethical issues in a way that can benefit those affected by them.
